title: My Menses and My MS: Why Can’t They Get Along?

content: For the last year or so, I’ve been going through changes. Let’s say that I’m “transitioning” or I’m in the “limbo” stage of my femininity. Then, I have MS. These two don’t get alone. Slowly heading to the “twilight zone” or menopause, my hormones are out of balance.

According to recent testing, I’m not officially in menopause because I still have my period and my hormone levels seem to be alright, but maaannn, I’m going crazy. Let’s take it from Day 1 of my cycle: I get my period. I’m very sleepy, sluggish, tired, etc., etc., etc. I get a couple of days of heavy flow, headaches, cramps, and pelvic pain, usually on the second and third day.

This week is the most aggressive one. All my MS symptoms skyrocket. My weakness gets worse. My hypersensitivity amplifies to the third power. The sensory overload is very hard to manage. My skin feels like it’s on fire. Even my clothes make my skin hurt. It’s like something hates me.

content: Then, between the fourth and seventh day, things improve, but then I feel like I’m starting to ovulate right after. I know it doesn’t make sense, and I know I’m not ovulating yet, but it feels like it. Translation: My right ovary hurts again.

Within a week, which would be day 14 or 15 of my cycle, I’m ovulating FOR REAL. Meaning, I have on-and-off pain in my right ovary. For some reason, it’s always the right one that hurts. I can spot or bleed sometimes. Mood swings, tiredness -- ugh yeah.

Seven days later, day 21, I start to feel cranky, get some headaches in the mix, feel emotional. I must admit, this is my worst week. I’m bloated, foggy, angry at the world. I tell you: Pray you don’t cross my path that week because I’m not too friendly. You’ll get a piece of me! Ha ha!

Day 28, I get my period, and everything starts ALL OVER AGAIN. You gotta love me! Most recently, I’ve had my period 4 to 5 days before I’m supposed to. So out of the whole month, I have maybe three good days. It’s awful!

content: Throughout these different stages of my menstrual cycle, my multiple sclerosis is angry. My symptoms go up and down, and when it’s not one, it’s the other. Or what’s worse, all of them at the same time. Mind you, these all commenced once I started to “cross the bridge.”

In the beginning of my MS journey, I didn’t quite notice any of these fluctuations. This really started over time as I have aged. Well, if this is the preamble to menopause, I can’t wait for the whole experience.

I’ve always had heavy periods. I also started really early. I had my first period when I was only 10 years old. What an abomination! I was introduced to womanhood too early, I feel. I’m now in my late 40s and the struggle is real. I’m sure other women will agree with me that menses and MS are declared public enemies. They fight over dominance and control of a body that is not even theirs, or is it?

content: As much as I want to keep my young looks, preserved by my hormones, I honestly can’t wait for this war to end. An MS-specialized neurologist offered to prescribe contraceptive pills so that I could have my periods only four times a year (every 3 months) and not 12 times a year.

I disregarded this option just because I think birth control pills are bad for you. But that’s just my opinion, of course. But right now, I’m questioning myself. I guess I just want the nonsense to stop.

As I navigate this new phase, I’m busier than ever and the challenge is bigger. It’s tough to deliver when your body is totally against you. I have multiple sclerosis, which is already enough, and now I’m in the middle of the hostilities between my menses and my MS.

I bring things up to my doctors as soon as they arise, and it’s good to know that I have options like a hormone-based contraceptive in the form of pill, injection, or an implant under the skin, an IUD (intrauterine device), a silicon hormone ring, or medical menopause treatment.

content: I prefer noninvasive treatments, so there’s a lot for me to consider before making a decision. As the trouper I’m known to be, I’m pushing through, in hopes it all shall pass. But maybe I could use some help? I don’t know yet.
